author: Ernst
title: Racing Car; a model still up to date !
review:
Overall 5 bricks : Although 36 years old still an up to date model recognizable as a Racing Car or Formula 1 car. Great model without stickers, easy to built and a great result with the basic bricks available in these years. A great addition for the vintage Lego collector and affordable.

Building 3 bricks : not the hardest built but fun to do with as result a very solid vehicle.

Parts 3 bricks : not the most spectacular parts of course but chosen very well. If you have a lot of  "old" bricks it is possible to make it yourself. The few special parts are the canopy and the side exhaust pipes.

Playability 3 bricks : when assembled not much playing possibilities aside from letting it race through your room.

Value 5 bricks : I found it in a lot I bought so almost for free. The average price on Bricklink is some â‚¬17,00 which is a good price if complete with instructions so in reach for every vintage Lego fan.

author: iwybs
title: Good for 1976, but it doesn't hold up in 2018
review:
Having acquired two Formula One cars from Speed Champions and the recent Creator Formula One car (Extreme Engines), I thought it would be fun to build this kit, or something very close to it, out of spare parts for comparison.  In concept, it's very similar to Extreme Engines: it can comfortably hold a minifig in the cockpit, though it's not explicitly designed to do so (it's also approximately the same size, at 21 studs in length compared to about 19 for the 2018 kit); it's from the most generic line of the time, explicitly meant to encourage rebuilding according to one's own imagination, rather than being a scale replica of anything specific; and it uses the most advanced slopes and greebles available at the time.  The raked lines of the windscreen and the nose look sharp, the eight 1x1 round bricks and two yellow taps behind the seat make a nice engine; and the two brackets with Technic pins at the back make nice exhaust pipes.  The red, black, and yellow color scheme is bold and bright.  So, it's a nice bit of history and it would have been very fun and impressive at the time. 

However, unlike many other kits of the late 1970s, it doesn't hold up well against its counterparts from the late 2010s.  For example, the lines and colors of the Galaxy Explorer have never been repeated just so, and there hasn't been a decent Moonbase for years.  The Yellow Castle still stands out compared to modern castles for its unusual color and its hinged walls.  Although Capital City has just as many features as Main Street, the lack of road plates means it doesn't feel quite the same.  Unique features like those are what continue to make many older sets desirable even though they may lack the sophisticated builds and details of modern sets.  In contrast, the specific feature set of this kit (a minifig-scaled Formula One car with four spinning wheels) has been replicated many times over the years, with increasing sophistication.  Compared to the recent Speed Champions and Creator F1 cars, the 1976 model is just ugly and boring.

TL;DR - A worthy effort for 1976, but an easy pass in 2018.  Don't hunt this one down on eBay unless you're a serious collector of Lego history.
